dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so this article we just read, it's, uh, quite a take on digital currencies and global power. I mean, it starts by saying Zuckerberg was actually *right*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so this article we just read, it's, uh, quite a take on digital currencies and global power. I mean, it starts by saying Zuckerberg was actually right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Perhaps Zuckerberg went too far when he suggested that the imminent rise of a Chinese digital currency could undermine overall dollar dominance of global trade and finance at least the large part that is legal, taxed, and regulated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Yeah, right? That a Chinese digital currency won't, like, actually undermine the dollar's global influence, at least not in the legal, regulated stuff. Which, um, I found surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, right? That a Chinese digital currency won't, like, actually undermine the dollar's global influence, at least not in the legal, regulated stuff. Which, um, I found surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas burdensome capital controls, its limits on foreign holdings of bonds and equities, and the general opaqueness of its financial system leave the renminbi many decades away from supplanting the dollar in the legal global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. But then it immediately pokes at US regulators, saying they have almost no power. Like, remember Europe dealing with Iran, and US regulators couldn't touch them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. But then it immediately pokes at U S regulators, saying they have almost no power. Like, remember Europe dealing with Iran, and U S regulators couldn't touch them?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, US regulators have vast power not only over domestic entities but also over any financial firms that need access to dollar markets, as Europe recently learned to its dismay when the US forced European banks to comply with severe restrictions on doing business with Iran.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally! And the Facebook and Instagram child pornography issue... they only removed twelve million pieces? That's, uh, still a massive problem. It really highlights the weakness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally! And the Facebook and Instagram child pornography issue... they only removed twelve million pieces? That's, uh, still a massive problem. It really highlights the weakness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook And Instagram Removed More Than 12 Million Pieces Of Child Porn

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it ties that into America's "weak markets, crumbling institutions," and China's "effortless capital flows." It's almost saying the renminbi could just become the standard, right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it ties that into America's weak markets, crumbling institutions, and China's effortless capital flows. It's almost saying the renminbi could just become the standard, right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americas deep and liquid markets, its strong institutions, and the rule of law will trump Chinese efforts to achieve currency dominance for a long time to come. Chinas burdensome capital controls...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it does. But then, it pivots a bit, saying control over the *legal* economy is a whole other thing. And that the legal economy, which includes, like, legitimate activities and taxes, is five times bigger than the underground one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it does. But then, it pivots a bit, saying control over the legal economy is a whole other thing. And that the legal economy, which includes, like, legitimate activities and taxes, is five times bigger than the underground one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The global underground economy, consisting mainly of tax evasion and criminal activities, but also terrorism, is much smaller than the legal economy (perhaps one-fifth the size), but it is still highly consequential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, makes the underground economy "highly inconsequential," according to the article. But here's where it gets really interesting for me: a US-backed digital currency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, makes the underground economy highly inconsequential, according to the article. But here's where it gets really interesting for me: a U S backed digital currency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The global underground economy... is much smaller than the legal economy (perhaps one-fifth the size), but it is still highly consequential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, the traceability! That blew my mind. It says a US-regulated digital currency wouldn't be traceable by US authorities. That's a *feature*?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the traceability! That blew my mind. It says a U S regulated digital currency wouldn't be traceable by U S authorities. That's a feature?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A US-regulated digital currency could in principle be required to be traceable by US authorities...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A feature, yeah! So, if North Korea wanted to, like, hire Russian nuclear scientists with it, or Iran funded terrorists, the US wouldn't be able to identify or stop them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A feature, yeah! So, if North Korea wanted to, like, hire Russian nuclear scientists with it, or Iran funded terrorists, the U S wouldn't be able to identify or stop them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...so that if North Korea were to use it to hire Russian nuclear scientists, or Iran were to use it to finance terrorist activity, they would run a high risk of being caught, and potentially even blocked.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But if it were run out of China, the US would suddenly have "many levers to pull." It's so counter-intuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if it were run out of China, the U S would suddenly have many levers to pull. It's so counter-intuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If, however, the digital currency were run out of China, the US would have far fewer levers to pull.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And it goes on to say Western regulators wouldn't even ban the Chinese digital currency, even if it took over, like, Africa or Latin America.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And it goes on to say Western regulators wouldn't even ban the Chinese digital currency, even if it took over, like, Africa or Latin America.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Western regulators could ultimately ban the use of Chinas digital currency, but that wouldnt stop it from being used in large parts of Africa, Latin America, and Asia...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, um, is a huge claim. And then it brings up Bitcoin. Saying existing cryptocurrencies are *perfect* for this purpose, and regulators have no incentive to rein them in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, um, is a huge claim. And then it brings up Bitcoin. Saying existing cryptocurrencies are perfect for this purpose, and regulators have no incentive to rein them in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To an extremely limited extent, they do. But regulators worldwide have huge incentives to rein in cryptocurrencies by sharply proscribing their use in banks and retail establishments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently, they make them super liquid, which enhances their value. But the Chinese digital renminbi? Couldn't be spent in, you know, the US or Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently, they make them super liquid, which enhances their value. But the Chinese digital renminbi? Couldn't be spent in, you know, the U S or Europe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such restrictions make existing cryptocurrencies highly illiquid and ultimately greatly limit their fundamental underlying value.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And even though China's will be "permissioned," the article argues the US *will* still see everything. But then it gets to Libra.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And even though China's will be permissioned, the article argues the U S will still see everything. But then it gets to Libra.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: True, when China announces its new digital currency, it will almost surely be permissioned: a central clearing house will in principle allow the Chinese government to see anything and everything. But the US will not.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, Libra! Unregulated by Swiss authorities, even worse than China, apparently. And no dollar peg means zero US insight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, Libra! Unregulated by Swiss authorities, even worse than China, apparently. And no dollar peg means zero U S insight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebooks Libra is also designed as a permissioned currency, in its case under the auspices of Swiss regulators. ... The fact that Libra will be pegged to the US dollar will give US authorities additional insight...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But there's "enormous fundamental demand" for it because its functionality is, like, unique. So, it argues we should promote tech-sponsored currencies unless they're genuinely inferior.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But there's enormous fundamental demand for it because its functionality is, like, unique. So, it argues we should promote tech-sponsored currencies unless they're genuinely inferior.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Still, given that Libras functionality can largely be duplicated with existing financial instruments, it is hard to see much fundamental demand for Libra except among those aiming to evade detection. ... Unless tech-sponsored currencies offer genuinely superior technology and this is not at all obvious they should be regulated in the same way as everyone else.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's, uh, quite the conclusion. That this battle isn't about profit or even the dollar's global role. And that, ultimately, "Western governments need to not start thinking about their response now, it's already far too late."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, uh, quite the conclusion. That this battle isn't about profit or even the dollar's global role. And that, ultimately, Western governments need to not start thinking about their response now, it's already far too late.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this battle is not simply over the profits from printing currency; ultimately, it is over the states ability to regulate and tax the economy in general, and over the US governments ability to use the dollars global role to advance its international policy aims. ... Western governments need to start thinking about their response now, before it is too late.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that "already far too late" really, uh, stuck with me. Itâ€™s pretty bleak, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that already far too late really, uh, stuck with me. It's pretty bleak, actually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Western governments need to start thinking about their response now, before it is too late.
